definition: Lu, vassal state at the time of the Zhou Dynasty 周朝|周朝[Zhou1 chao2], located in the southwest of present-day Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1], birthplace of Confucius
(bound form) crass/stupid/rude/(used to represent the sounds of "ru", "lu" etc in loanwords)
surname Lu/Lu, ancient state of China 魯國|鲁国[Lu3 guo2]/Lu, short name for Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1]
country/nation/state/national/CL:個|个[ge4]
surname Guo
person from Shandong/often refers to Confucius

sentences.english: The King of Lu led the army by himself.
sentences.chinese: 魯國由魯王親自帶兵迎戰。

sentences.english: Confucius was a well-known teacher in the Lu Kingdom 2000 years ago.
sentences.chinese: 孔子是一位2000多年前魯國的知名的老師。

sentences.english: Later when the state of qi guanzhong ruler, and cao foam did lu general.
sentences.chinese: 後來管仲當了齊國的宰相，而曹沫做了魯國的將軍。

sentences.english: This time the scholars asked to meet him again.
sentences.chinese: 這回又有一些魯國學者求見。

sentences.english: Lu, all went to watch for this state is slack.
sentences.chinese: 魯國君臣整日前去觀看，對國事就懈怠了。

sentences.english: A countryman from the state of Lu sent to king Song Yuangong two knots that were difficult to untie.
sentences.chinese: 魯國的一個鄉下人送給宋元公兩個難以解開的連環結。

sentences.chinese: 這些女樂文馬陳列在魯國都城南面高門這個地方。

sentences.english: The pledge between Lu and other states in the Spring and Autumn period has different characteristics.
sentences.chinese: 春秋時期魯國與列國的盟誓有不同的特徵。

sentences.english: Because of this, Qi thought Lu was  timid and then relaxed.
sentences.chinese: 於是齊國軍隊認爲魯國膽小不敢進攻，便懈怠下來。

sentences.chinese: 於是就把擾亂政治的魯國大夫少正卯殺了。

sentences.english: When he passed the State of Lu, some local scholars wanted to see him.
sentences.chinese: 當他路過魯國時，魯國有些學者想登門求見。

sentences.chinese: 當他路過魯國時，魯國有些學者想登門求見。

sentences.english: When Confucius ascended the Eastern Mountain he realized how small the State of Lu was.
sentences.chinese: 孔子登上東山往下看，便覺得魯國小了。

sentences.english: King Wu was very pleased. He accepted the rare gift and rewarded the ambassador generously.
sentences.chinese: 武王非常高興，接受了珍貴的禮物並重賞魯國使者。

definition: Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏子, hero of book 晏子春秋
Zi Gong or Duanmu Ci 端木賜|端木赐[Duan1 mu4 Ci4] (520 BC-), disciple of Confucius
the state of Chu, one of the most important of the small states contending for power in China between 770 and 223 BC, located around present-day Hubei
Yan Hui (521-481 BC), disciple of Confucius, also known as Yan Yuan 顏淵|颜渊[Yan2 Yuan1]
Duke Wen of Jin (697-628 BC, reigned 636-628 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Qi state of Western Zhou and the Warring states (1122-265 BC), centered in Shandong

Yan, a vassal state of Zhou in modern Hebei and Liaoning/north Hebei/the four Yan kingdoms of the Sixteen Kingdoms, namely: Former Yan 前燕 (337-370), Later Yan 後燕|后燕 (384-409), Southern Yan 南燕 (398-410), Northern Yan 北燕 (409-436)
Yang Zhu (c. 440-360 BC), Chinese philosopher advocating ethical egoism
Li Guang (-119 BC), Han dynasty general, nicknamed Flying General 飛將軍|飞将军 and much feared by the Xiongnu 匈奴
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
prime minister (in ancient China)
Sunwu county in Heihe 黑河[Hei1 he2], Heilongjiang
monarch
Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
